node.title: Excitement, fear and uncertainty: How Tasmanians are feeling about borders reopening
node.description: On the eve of Tasmania's borders reopening to fully vaccinated travellers, emotions are running high. Five locals share what the state's long-awaited reopening means to them.Â
node.content:
["After nearly two years of closures and restrictions, the reopening of Tasmania's borders has brought with it a range of emotions for most locals.\u00a0", "Tasmania will open its borders to all fully vaccinated Australians from December 15, although control measures such as travel registrations and testing for those coming from high risk places will remain.\u00a0", "We asked Tasmanians how they're feeling ahead of \u2014 relatively \u2014 free travel finally being allowed.\u00a0", "
Persia Brooks, nursing student, Swansea\u00a0
", "", "
Nursing student Persia Brooks has enjoyed living on 'island time'.(ABC News: Owain Stia-James)
", "\"What I've loved about borders being shut is we've really kind of stepped back into the 1990s.", "\"I've really loved the slower paced island time, being just not as busy on the roads, going out camping and not having hundreds of people at the same camp zone, but also just slowing down a bit.", "\"We've been cut off from the rest of the world for two years now and become a bit more of the hermit state, compared to many other parts of Australia.", "\"As someone who's travelled mostly every year for a couple of months to now not travelling at all, it's definitely made me rethink what I'll be doing in the future.", "\"I really want to go to Africa first, the drawcard there is I've really wanted to do a lot of Africa, I've only done maybe two or three countries there, and just do a road trip around there.\"", "", "
Persia Brooks is looking forward to travelling internationally again.(ABC News: Owain Stia-James)
", "
Angela O'Neill, medical accounts manager, Kingston
", "\"It's exciting for Tasmania, for businesses, for young people, for people who want to get out and about and people who want to come to Tasmania\u00a0\u2014\u00a0but from my point of view, I'm just a little bit afraid for my loved ones.", "", "
Angela O'Neill is feeling anxious knowing COVID is on its way to Tasmania.(ABC News)
", "\"I've got a husband and father both who've got autoimmune diseases and it makes them vulnerable so it does really make me worry for them and not just them but other vulnerable people.", "\"We've all talked about our freedoms and getting out and about but there are so many Australians that are invisible and they tend to be people with chronic illnesses and disabilities and people who need protecting from all of us.\u00a0", "\"In the last two years, in Tasmania we've been quite protected apart from when we had our first outbreak, since then we've kind of been having our freedoms, albeit at home.\u00a0", "\"I've already started to talk to friends about vaccination status, who's vaccinated, I really will want to be around people who are vaccinated and probably not get out and about as much.", "\"COVID is coming and there will certainly be people who end up with it.\"", "
Alondra Lisica, student, Hobart
", "", "
Hobart student Alondra Lisica has found it challenging being separated from loved ones.(ABC News: Maren Preuss)
", "\"With the borders shut, for me, I'm the only person in my family that's in Tasmania, the rest of the family is in Sydney or other places in Australia so it was really hard for me to see my family and I didn't get to see them for a long time, like for Easter.", "\"I haven't seen my new nephew who is\u00a0half a year old now.", "\"Also I'm really close with my cousins because I don't have any siblings at all, so I rely on them as my siblings.", "\"It's really hard not being with them or going to see them.", "\"I'm feeling excited that I can actually see my family, a lot, and I'm happy I can actually go places where I want to go.\"", "", "
Alondra Lisica is eager to reunite with her extended family interstate.(ABC News: Selina Ross)
", "
Joel Taylor, truck driver, Deloraine
", "\"As a truck driver in the last couple of years it's been very stressful at times, making sure COVID tests have been done before we get to borders, having passes in place, having our log books right and keeping ourselves safe all at the same time.\u00a0", "\"You're sharing things like showers with thousands of truck drivers a day and dining rooms, it's hard and stressful and scary.\u00a0", "", "
Truck driver Joel Taylor is hoping open borders will allow him a more normal life.(ABC News: Selina Ross)
", "\"Before COVID hit we were just travelling Australia, doing our thing, and all of a sudden they've got borders shut and we've got to do border passes and COVID tests.", "\"Life on the road has been pretty good during the pandemic, quiet with cars and caravans, just been trucks and essential people, less accidents but that's all starting to come back in again.", "", "
Joel Taylor estimates he's had 120 COVID tests in the last two years.(ABC News: Selina Ross)
", "\"With borders open, I'm looking forward to travelling home a lot easier, we won't be locked in our rooms on the Spirit [of Tasmania], all that stuff.", "", "
Sarah Fielding is nervous about potential lockdowns once borders reopen.(ABC News: Rick Eaves)
", "
Sarah Fielding, small business owner, Ulverstone
", "\"I think it's time that we do reopen the borders and learn to live amongst it all, hopefully everything's been put in place for us all and we'll proceed with caution.", "\"We mostly feel nervous about whether we have continued snap lockdowns as such, hopefully not, it's hard on businesses to be starting and opening as we watched our Victorian and New South Wales people, hopefully it just continues as it is.", "\"We're trying to get a website built so if we do have snap lockdowns, to make the business viable we hope to be able to offer faceless deliver.", "\"The separation of family has been hard.\u00a0I have a brother overseas, we were hoping to go over to the US and see him but obviously that's been shelved.\u00a0", "\"I think it's been hard on human nature, that isolation feeling, it's confusing and overwhelming at times.\u00a0", "", "
Sarah Fielding has been cautiously preparing her business for the new COVID-normal.(ABC News: Rick Eaves)
